ltp_activity_data.name: A friendly chat
ltp_activity_data.text:
Talk to your teen about something that they are interested in! ğŸ˜ƒ

âš½ An easy way to start talking to your teen is to ask them about something they are interested in. For example, you could talk about sports, books, movies, friends, music, celebrities, or school.

ğŸ‘‚ You may not find everything your teen shares to be interesting, but itâ€™s important to show enthusiasm and an eagerness to learn.

ltp_activity_data.name: Create your own Recipe
ltp_activity_data.text:
Let your teen come up with a new meal idea! 

ğŸš Create a new dish with Your Teen using ingredients they love!

ğŸ”µ Together, choose two ingredients, and ask your teen to prepare a meal using them. For example: chicken and spinach, tomatoes and rice, maize and pumpkin.

ğŸ“ If you enjoy the meal, make it something your family eats weekly, and ask your teen to write it down for you. Give the meal a name and explain how to make it. 

âœ¨ If your teen notices that you are learning from their cooking, it will boost their confidence!

ltp_activity_data.name: Reflect on the positive
ltp_activity_data.text:
Spread Positivity! ğŸŒˆ

ğŸ’¡ Together, take a minute to think about all the things you did today. 

â˜€ï¸ Take turns sharing one positive or fun thing that happened. This could be something small, like feeling good because you cleaned the house, or something big, like spending time with family and friends. 

â° Try doing this every day - even more on the days it feels like you have not done anything special.

ltp_activity_data.name: Whatâ€™s new?
ltp_activity_data.text:
Learning is fun! ğŸ“

â“ Ask your teen to think of a new, fun skill you could learn together. 
For example: keeping a ball in the air with your foot, juggling, making soup, moonwalking, whistling, saying the alphabet backwards, learning all the countries in Africa. 

ğŸ”„ Take turns trying out the new skill.  Make sure to praise each other and learn and play together!

ğŸ’› Approach learning the skill in a kind and fun way, and do not judge your teen or yourself for your ability in the skill.

ltp_activity_data.name: Dance moves
ltp_activity_data.text:
Let's get moving! ğŸ‘‹ Dancing is a great way to exercise, have fun, and bond with your teen at the same time! You both get to express yourselves in a fun, relaxed way.  ğŸµ 

This game can be played in pairs or a group with everyone taking turns being the leader:

ğŸ“± Let your teen choose a song they like and create a set of dance moves.

ğŸ‘€ First person does a dance move and everyone else copies it.

â˜€ï¸ Donâ€™t worry about perfecting the dance moves, itâ€™s all about having fun together!

ğŸ’¡ If you want to, you can perform your dance for the household!

ltp_activity_data.name: Dance Activity
ltp_activity_data.text:
Try something new and learn a dance challenge with your teen! âœ¨ Have fun!

â­ Dancing is a great way to have fun together while being creative and moving your body!

ğŸ“± If your teen uses the app TikTok, suggest doing a dance challenge together.

ğŸ˜ƒ Ask your teen to choose their favourite dance and learn it with them.

ğŸ‰ Itâ€™s okay if you canâ€™t dance well, have fun and try not to take it too seriously! 

ğŸ’¡ You do not have to post the video to learn the dance. You can keep it as a memory between you and your teen.

ltp_activity_data.name: Check-in chat
ltp_activity_data.text:
Actively checking in on one another helps to keep relationships healthy! â­

Ask each other questions: â€œWhat made you happy today?â€ ğŸ‘‚ â€œWhat was difficult today?â€ ğŸ‘‚ â€œHow can I help you?â€ ğŸ‘‚

For this to help, your teen needs to feel safe while sharing things with you. Be open to their responses. ğŸ’š Teens tend to be more honest when they trust that what they say will not be used against them later.

Go easy on yourself if your teen does not want to share their problems with you. ğŸ’™ Often, teens are afraid to share as they are scared they will get in trouble. Getting upset with them wonâ€™t help - keep showing you love them and give them time! ğŸŒ·

ltp_activity_data.name: Express Yourself
ltp_activity_data.text:
Dancing makes people happy!

ğŸŒˆ This game can be played in pairs or as a group - stand facing each other or in a circle.

ğŸµ Together, choose a fun and upbeat song to play and a person to start the game by creating one dance move.

ğŸ‘€ The person to their right must copy that dance move and add their own move to it.

âœ¨ Go around the circle, each person adding their own dance move to the full song.

ğŸ”„ The first one who forgets someone's dance moves or does it in the wrong order chooses the next song and starts the game again.

ğŸ‰ Try new dance moves with this game and have fun!

ltp_activity_data.name: 2 Truths, 1 Lie
ltp_activity_data.text:
This is a fun, quick game, and the point of it is to learn things about each other. Make your answers as interesting as possible! ğŸ¨

ğŸ’¡ Ask your teen to think of 3 facts about themselves. 2 must be true, 1 must be a lie. 
ğŸ”· Here are some examples: I hate bananas, I have travelled to Kenya, my favourite subject in school was maths.

ğŸ‘€ Share the facts with your teen and ask them to guess which one is a lie. 

ğŸ”„ Now ask them to do the same, and guess theirs.

Did you learn anything new about your teen, or did they learn anything new about you? ğŸ’›

ltp_activity_data.name: Yes, No or Maybe
ltp_activity_data.text:
Are you tired of hearing your teen say yes, no, or maybe to all of your questions? Turn your chat into a game, and donâ€™t allow one-word answers. ğŸˆ

ğŸ”´ Teens are known to give one-word answers to avoid talking. 

ğŸ’¡ When you would like to really know how your teen is doing, you can turn your chat into a game. 

â­ Take turns asking each other questions. The only rule is that you cannot use one-word responses, such as Yes, No, Maybe, Fine, and Okay.

âš½ You can ask about things your teen likes or what they did today. For example, how was your day? What are you excited for? Is there anything worrying you?

ğŸ”„ It is important to let your teen ask a question as well. Trust is built when your teen can see that you are also sharing your life with them, and not only trying to learn about their life.

ltp_activity_data.name: Movie World
ltp_activity_data.text:
Leaving the busy and stressful world behind can be good for our health. ğŸŒ± Take a moment to escape with your teen by creating a superhero story together!

ğŸˆ Ask your teen to imagine that they are a superhero and what their superpowers would be. Flying? Time travel? Mind reading? Super Strength?

âœ¨ Ask them how they would use these superpowers, and why. 

ğŸŒˆ Help them give their superhero a name, an outfit, and a sidekick, and act it out. If your teen does not want to act, that is fine - talking about it is just as good! 

ğŸ‘‘ Now, let them make up a superhero for you. Play the part! You can ask questions, like who the villain would be, or how you became a superhero. 

ğŸ’¡ Create a story - what happens to the characters? Is it an action story? Is it a thriller, space, sport, adventure, or romance?

â¡ï¸ Next time you play this game, you could create a new story or superhero with your teen or continue the story you started together.

ltp_activity_data.name: Get Active
ltp_activity_data.text:
Exercise is a great way to spend time together and it is so good for your health. ğŸŒ± Find a sport or exercise that both you and your teen want to do and try it out together! 

â° Even walking for 10 minutes a day is good for you. 

âš½ Together you can walk, run, play soccer, swim, dance, or do any other sport..

ğŸ† Together, think of ways to make it even more fun. Can you jog to a certain point? Take turns being the coach? Can there be a small, free reward, like getting to decide the next activity?

ğŸŒˆ Exercise becomes easier and more enjoyable the more you do it. 

ğŸ”„ If you or your teen do not like the first exercise you pick, try a new exercise.

ltp_activity_data.name: Make up a story
ltp_activity_data.text:
Creating stories together is a great way to learn the art of storytelling - and to build your teenâ€™s creativity! ğŸ“–

ğŸ”Ÿ With your teen, come up with 10 words to use. They can be any words you want! For example: banana, spaceship, fish, water, painting, wasp nest, cooking, wedding.

ğŸ‚ Start your story with, â€œOnce upon a time, there was aâ€¦â€ and make sure you use one of the words from the list in your sentence. For example, â€œOnce upon a time, there was a family who worked on a *banana* farm.â€

ğŸ“ Let your teen make up the next sentence using another word from the list.

ğŸ”„ Take turns until you have used as many words from the list as you can, or until you have finished your story. 

ğŸ”” Be as creative as possible with your story and do not tell your teen what to say. It does not need to be a real story to be a good story!

ğŸ Ask your teen what their favourite part of the story was, and tell them yours!

ltp_activity_data.name: Take A Pause with your teen
ltp_activity_data.text:
Take a pause with your teen. This helps them deal with stress in a healthy way!

â° You could take a pause before dinner, after school, before school, or before bedtime.

ğŸ‘‚ Sit down together and close your eyes. Listen to your breath as it goes in and out. Notice how you feel. 

â­ Take 5 more deep breaths.

ğŸ‘€ When you are ready, open your eyes again. Do you feel any different? 

â¸ Ask your teen what it was like to take a pause. Listen and accept whatever they say about it.

ltp_activity_data.name: Name That Tune
ltp_activity_data.text:
Listening to music is a great way to lower your stress and have fun with your family. ğŸ’š

ğŸ“» Gather your family members and choose one person to play or sing a song.

â“ Everyone else must guess the name and artist of the song.

ğŸ‰ The first one to guess it right becomes the next person to sing or play a song. 

ğŸ”„ Keep going around until everyone has been able to play their favourite song and let the rest hear.

ltp_activity_data.name: Pass the ball
ltp_activity_data.text:
Games are a great, fun way to spend time with your family! 

3ï¸âƒ£ This game is best with at least 3 people.

âš½ Find a ball to play. If you cannot find a ball, choose an item you can safely throw around. For example, a bottle cap or a plastic cup.

â¡ï¸ Start in a circle and pass the ball around. 

ğŸ‘‹ Start throwing the ball in new directions (up, down, straight, curved, rolling on the ground) and with different forces (hard, soft, medium). You can bounce the ball, throw it in the air, and catch it a few times before passing it. 

âœ¨ When everyone gets good at catching the ball, you can start moving around the room, still passing the ball. 

â­ Can you throw the ball under the leg? Behind the back? Over your head? Block a pass? Have fun with it!

ltp_activity_data.name: Make Housework Fun
ltp_activity_data.text:
Turn your chores into games! ğŸ† 

â˜€ï¸ Making housework fun is a good way to teach your teen to be responsible and to rely on themselves. 

ğŸ“ Together, make a list of all the chores that must be done in your home. 

ğŸ’¡ Make sure the tasks are fair and things your teen can do. For example, washing up, sweeping, mopping, making the beds, and laundry.

ğŸ”„ Each week, let a different person in the family choose a chore first.

ğŸµ Play some music or turn on the radio. Music is a great way to make a boring task fun!

âœ… Tick off the tasks when they are done so you can see your progress as a family. You could offer small rewards as motivation to complete activities.

ğŸ“º For example, you could let your teen watch more TV, spend more time with their friends, choose what they want for dinner, or have something sweet if they do their chores in a fair amount of time.

â“ If your child does not complete a chore, ask them why, and come up with a fair consequence together.

ltp_activity_data.name: Iâ€™m Going on a Picnic and I Will Bringâ€¦
ltp_activity_data.text:
Memory games are a fun way to strengthen our brains! 

ğŸ‚ Think of all the things you would have at your dream picnic. 

ğŸˆ The first person says, â€œOn Saturday, I am going to the park to have a picnic. To this picnic, I will bring...â€ and they say one thing they will bring to the picnic.

ğŸ… For example: a sandwich, a ball, a blanket, forks, cups, a dog, or coca cola.

ğŸ”” The second person adds to the first person's list, but must start at the beginning: â€œOn Saturday, I am going to the park to have a picnic. To this picnic, I will bring...â€ and say the item that the first person said AND then add their own item to the list.

ğŸ”„ Each time you add an item, you must say all previous items first - in the correct order!

â­ Each person adds to the list, while remembering all the previous items. 

ğŸ‘€ If everyone has a turn, keep going and building your list. The first person to forget an item restarts the game!

ltp_activity_data.name: This is who I am
ltp_activity_data.text:
Self-esteem is the way you value yourself, either in a positive or negative way. Helping your teen to have high self-esteem is a recipe for success! ğŸ†

â­Share with your teen 3 things you like about yourself!

3ï¸âƒ£ Ask your teen to tell you 3 things they like about themselves. 
For example: I am great at treating others kindly. I am great at styling my hair. I am great at football. âš½

If your teen does not feel comfortable sharing these, ask them to write them down. ğŸ“

ltp_activity_data.name: Things I like about others and me
ltp_activity_data.text:
Here is an activity to help you and your teen notice the good parts of themselves.. 

â˜€ï¸Ask your teen to share 3 things they like about a friend or someone they admire, like a celebrity.

â“ Ask them if they share any of these qualities, too.

ğŸ’™ You can do the same: share with your teen the qualities you like about yourself or about someone you admire - and what you like about your teen!

ltp_activity_data.name: Make a family wish list
ltp_activity_data.text:
Wish lists are a great way to set, plan and keep track of your goals and dreams. ğŸŒ· 
ğŸ“ To start your wish list, gather your family together and grab pens and paper. 
ğŸš² Allow each family member to write a list of goals and experiences they want to achieve this year.
ğŸ‚ For example: exercise daily, read 1 book a month, make a new friend, learn to bake a cake, learn to juggle, or go watch the local soccer team play. 
ğŸ”” Once you have finished, put the list up where everyone can see it daily.
ğŸ‰ As members of the family reach their goals, tick them off the list and celebrate each goal reached. 
â“ As the year goes on, there might be some items some of you have not achieved. Talk to your family about whether you still want to reach this goal or whether the goal has changed. 
ğŸ”‘ If you still want to achieve the goal, discuss with your family what you need to do to tick the goal off your wish list.

ltp_activity_data.name: Weekly Goal Setting
ltp_activity_data.text:
Letâ€™s set some goals â­

â° It can be helpful to set smaller weekly goals that are easier to reach. This helps us reach our larger goals over time.

ğŸ’¡Ask your teen for one goal that they would like to achieve this week. 

ğŸ”„ Make sure this goal is *specific* and  *achievable* to reach in 1 week.

ğŸ’š You can also share your own weekly goal with your teen and support each other so you can both achieve your goals.

ğŸ‰ Make sure to praise and celebrate your teen for their hard work towards reaching their goal.

ğŸ”” If your teen does not reach their goal, that is okay. Discuss with your teen the steps they still need to take or how they could reach it a different way.

ltp_activity_data.name: Three cakes and a candle
ltp_activity_data.text:
Working towards big goals can be hard! Here is a way you can help your teen set new goals for the things they want to achieve. ğŸ‘‘

ğŸ‘‘ Ask your teen to come up with three things that they are good at, and discuss what they did to become so good at them. For example: keeping their room neat, helping your family with housework, or playing a sport.

ğŸ† Next, ask your teen what they wish they were good at. 

ğŸ”‘ Remind them that it took work and practice to become good at the skills they have. They will have to do the same for any new goal.

â° Help your teen break down their goal and set up smaller goals they need to achieve to reach their greater goal. 

ğŸ“ It is much easier to achieve a goal if you write it down! This way, you can be reminded of it as you work towards it.

â˜€ï¸ For example, if the goal is to be good at football, small weekly goals could be to go to football practice 2 times per week, run at least 1 km 5 times per week, and learn about the sport from other football players in the community or from books or videos they find. 

âœ… It is important to write down these smaller goals and let your teen tick off each task as they do them each week. Seeing themselves reach smaller goals will keep them motivated to achieve the big goal!

ltp_activity_data.name: Role Playing
ltp_activity_data.text:
Letâ€™s start acting! â­

â“Role playing common stressful social moments with your teen allows them to practise how to respond so they are prepared if this moment does happen. ğŸŒ·

âœ¨ Ask your teen if they want to role play with you. You can also suggest a topic. For example, asking someone on a date, saying no to drugs/alcohol/sexting, dealing with a bully, getting a bad grade, or dealing with gossip.

ğŸŒ™ Your teen could play the role of a friend asking you to drink at a party. You could role play an underage teen who does not want to drink. Encourage your teen to be silly and really get into character with them. 

â¯ï¸ After you act out the scene, it is important to talk to your teen about the actions that you role played. You can act out this scenario as many times as you like!

ltp_activity_data.name: Traffic Lights
ltp_activity_data.text:
A group activity is a great way to bond with others! ğŸ’› 

ğŸ’¡ Choose one person to turn and face a wall. This will be the traffic officer. 

ğŸ Everyone else will begin the game at the other side of the room, or if you are outside, at a starting line. Set a long distance between the traffic officer and the players. 

ğŸ’š The game begins when the officer shouts â€œGreenâ€, and everyone can start moving towards the traffic officer at any speed they choose. 

ğŸ”´ The officer can shout â€œRed!â€ at any time, without looking behind them. When they shout this, everyone must stop and freeze! 

â¸ The officer turns around to see if everyone is frozen. If they see anyone moving, they have to send them back to the start line.

ğŸ† The winner is the first person to get to the officer without being sent back to the start.

ğŸ‘‘ The winner then becomes the traffic officer and you can play another round!

ltp_activity_data.name: Cooking with Maths
ltp_activity_data.text:
Cooking can help your boy or girl start learning maths!
ğŸ’š Invite your girl or boy to help you cook for your family, or to choose something they would like to cook 
;
ğŸ… Ask your boy or girl to count different ingredients. Help them if itâ€™s difficult!

ğŸ”Ÿ Help your girl or boy to understand adding and subtracting quantities 

ğŸ“ Encourage your boy or girl to recognise numbers on packaging

 ğŸ‘€ Ask your girl or boy about the different sizes of ingredients - e.g. which is bigger/biggest?
;
ğŸ”„ Think about when you will cook together again! You can also practise understanding numbers and quantities during other activities like shopping or building/making things

ltp_activity_data.name: Following Instructions
ltp_activity_data.text:
ğŸ‘‚ Play a game in which your boy or girl listens to and tries to remember strings of instructions.
This will be useful in school, at home, and later in life!
;
Start with just one instruction using an object in your home. For example â€œtouch the red ballâ€ ğŸ”´

Slowly add more instructions (e.g â€œthen pick up the cup â˜•), but tell your girl or boy that they can only start once youâ€™ve finished giving the instructions.
See how many your boy or girl can follow without forgetting!
;
ğŸ”„ Now swap roles! Itâ€™s your boy or girlâ€™s turn to give you instructions! They can use the same objects if they want.
You can also try this game with a group of girls and boys! Make sure they take turns :)

ltp_activity_data.name: One-on-One Time
ltp_activity_data.text:
ğŸ’š Spending time just with your girl or boy and taking an interest in them can improve your relationship. 
;
ğŸ‘€ When your boy or girl is playing alone or occupying themselves quietly, join them and show interest in what they are doing.

ğŸ‘‚Ask questions about their activity, and listen to them.

Let your girl or boy lead the activity, follow them to build their confidence and autonomy ğŸ˜ƒ.

ğŸ‘€ Say what you see - describing everything and supporting your boyâ€™s or girlâ€™s actions.
;
Be positive, praise your girl or boy, and enjoy spending this time with them ğŸ˜ƒğŸ’š

ltp_activity_data.name: Playtime with Books
ltp_activity_data.text:
ğŸ“– Book sharing will help your boy or girl learn and is a fun, playful activity to spend quality time together.

â° Choose a time when you wonâ€™t be disturbed, and try to stop any distractions - e.g. turn off the TV and put away phones.

ğŸ“– If your girl or boy wants to choose a book, thatâ€™s fine, otherwise choose for them.
;

ğŸ’š Sit close together and follow your boy or girl attention and lead. 
Point at things, name and repeat words. Help them to learn more about what interests them in the book ğŸ‘€ 
If there are words or numbers in the book, ask and help your girl or boy recognise letters numbers, and simple words ğŸ’¡. 

Link things in the books to your child's life, and use words about emotions and talk about them! ğŸ˜ƒ.
;
ğŸ”„ If possible, start a regular routine to read together when your girl or boy isnâ€™t too tired or hungry.
Reading together is one of the best ways to help your boy or girl learn and prepare for success in school! ğŸ“

ltp_activity_data.name: Playtime with Books
ltp_activity_data.text:
ğŸ“– Book sharing will help your girl or boy learn and is a fun, playful activity to spend quality time together

â° Choose a time when you wonâ€™t be disturbed, and try to stop any distractions - e.g. turn off the TV and put away phones

ğŸ“– If your boy or girl wants to choose a book, thatâ€™s fine, otherwise choose for them
;

ğŸ’š Sit close together and follow your girl or boy attention and lead 
Point at things, name and repeat words. Help them to learn more about what interests them in the book ğŸ‘€ 

Link things in the books to your child's life, and use words about emotions and talk about them! ğŸ˜ƒ
;
ğŸ”„ If possible, start a regular routine to read together when your girl or boy isnâ€™t too tired or hungry
Reading together is one of the best ways to help your boy or girl learn and prepare for success in school! ğŸ“

ltp_activity_data.name: I Spy!
ltp_activity_data.text:
ğŸ‘€ I spy is a fun game to play with your girl or boy that will help them learn about letters and words!
;

Choose an object or a thing around you, and donâ€™t tell your boy or girl what it is. It should be something that your boy or girl knows the word for. For example â€œballâ€ âš½

ğŸ‘€ Then say â€œI spy with my little eye, something beginning with *and then say the first letter of the word* which in this case is â€œbâ€

Your girl or boy should look around and guess what the object is. When they guess it right, praise them and swap roles! If they canâ€™t get it, give them some clues, like â€œitâ€™s roundâ€ or â€œitâ€™s black and whiteâ€. âœ…
;

Play this game with as many objects as possible and as many different letters! Help your boy or girl to learn about the different letters and sounds in words. This will help them learn to read at home and school. ğŸ“

ltp_activity_data.name: Categorising and Organising
ltp_activity_data.text:
Help your girl or boy to learn by sorting objects and things! ğŸ”µğŸ”·

Your boy or girl will learn by understanding how things fit and group together (eg, bear = animal, mango = fruit, blue = colour) ğŸ§¸

Find a book with different pictures and help your girl or boy to find things in a particular category (e.g. â€œFind all of the animalsâ€) ğŸ‘€

Find *safe* objects in the house, get your boy or girl to group them by colour, size, or types of object (cups, plates). Then make more complicated categories (e.g. small cups, big cups) â˜•
;
ğŸ”„ You can play the categorising game anywhere! Just look around and ask your girl or boy to find things from the category you say!

ltp_activity_data.name: What Letter is This?
ltp_activity_data.text:
Playing games with letters can help your boy or girl learn the alphabet and how letters are put together to make words.

ğŸ“ Write a letter on a piece of card or paper (e.g. â€œpâ€)

ğŸ‘‚ Say the letter out loud and ask your girl or boy to say it too!

Ask your boy or girl to say some words that begin with the letter â€œpâ€, give them clues like â€œWhat starts with â€œpâ€? Plantâ€¦ What else? ğŸŒ±

ğŸ‘€ Ask your girl or boy to look for objects in your house that begin with a letter (eg â€œpâ€ for plate). Help them find things.
;
ğŸ”„ Try a new letter every day!

ltp_activity_data.name: Riddles Help Boys and Girls Learn
ltp_activity_data.text:
Riddles and puzzles are a fun way to build thinking skills! ğŸ’¡
;
Do you remember any riddles from your childhood? If you canâ€™t then make one up, they can be very simple! ğŸ˜ƒ
Like â€œWhat can you see at night but not in the dayâ€ Answer: â€œThe moonâ€ ğŸŒ™

If your girl or boy is finding them difficult, try an easy one like: â€œWhat is round, bouncy and can be thrown or kicked?â€ Answer: â€œA ballâ€ âš½

Your boy or girl can also try making riddles! ğŸ’¡
;
You can have fun with riddles anywhere at any time - like traveling on a bus, walking to school or in a car ğŸš—

ltp_activity_data.name: What's New?
ltp_activity_data.text:
Learning is fun! ğŸ“

â“ Ask your girl or boy to think of a new, fun skill you could learn together. 
For example: keeping a ball in the air with your foot, juggling, making soup, moonwalking, whistling, saying the alphabet backwards, learning all the states in Mexico. 

ğŸ”„ Take turns trying out the new skill. Make sure to praise each other and learn and play together!

ğŸ’› Approach learning the skill in a kind and fun way, and do not judge your boy or girl or yourself for your ability in the skill. 

ğŸ˜ƒ Once you have mastered the skill, choose another skill to learn together.

ltp_activity_data.name: Make up a Story
ltp_activity_data.text:
Creating stories together is a great way to have fun with imagination - and to build your girl or boyâ€™s creativity! ğŸ“–
;
5ï¸âƒ£ With your boy or girl, come up with 5 words to use. They can be any words you want! For example: banana, spaceship, fish, water, painting, cooking, wedding. If you need to remember them, write them clearly on a paper with your girl or boy.

ğŸ‚ Start your story with, â€œOnce upon a time, there was aâ€¦â€ and use one of the words from the list in the first part. For example, â€œOnce upon a time, there was a family who worked on a *banana* farm.â€

ğŸ“ Let your boy or girl make up the next part using another word from the list.
;
ğŸ”„ Take turns until you have used all the words and created a story. 

ğŸ”” Be creative and do not tell your girl or boy what to say. It does not need to be a real story to be fun!

ğŸ Ask your boy or girl what their favourite part of the story was, and tell them yours!

ltp_activity_data.name: Playing with Clothes
Playing with Vegetables
ltp_activity_data.text:
ğŸŒ± Help your girl or boy learn by thinking and talking about vegetables!

ğŸ… Mix together 2-3 different ingredients of your choice (like onions, tomatoes and corn example). Say: â€œHelp me sort these vegetables into piles?â€ Try sorting them by size.
;
ğŸ˜ƒ Remind me!
Talk about your childâ€™s experiences. Ask questions and wait for answers. Follow your childâ€™s interests. 
â€œCan you help me remember what is at the market?â€ â€œDo they sell carrots at the market?â€ â€œDo they sell anything yellow at the market?â€ â€œWhat else do they sell?â€ â€œCan you think of other things they sell?â€
;
ğŸ’¡Can you think of something similar?
Say: We are going to think of some things that are similar or different from what I tell you. So listen carefully!â€
Here is a tomato. Can you think of something else that is red like a tomato? ğŸ…
Can you think of something else that is round like a tomato? âš½

ltp_activity_data.name: Animals
ltp_activity_data.text:
ğŸ§¸ Active animals: Take turns with Your Child doing animal actions: Hop like a frog, stretch like a cat, run like a dog, slither like a snake, flap like a bird
;
ğŸ’¡All the animals we can think of - think about groups of animals!
What are all the animals we can think of that have feathers?
What are all the animals we can think of that eat plants? ğŸŒ±
What are all the animals we can think of that lay eggs?
;
ğŸ˜ƒ Counting rabbits
ğŸ”Ÿ Find 10 rocks and put them in a line, tell your girl or boy that they are rabbits!
Ask them to count the rabbits!
Put the rabbits into 2 equal piles. Ask your boy or girl to give you 3 rabbits. Say â€œIf you give me 3, how many rabbits do you have?â€

ltp_activity_data.name: Active Counting
ltp_activity_data.text:
ğŸ‘‹ Clap, hop, jump: Play the following game with Your Child. Make it active!

1ï¸âƒ£ Clap hands 1 time. 2ï¸âƒ£ Clap hands 2 times.
1ï¸âƒ£ Jump 1 time. 2ï¸âƒ£ Jump 2 times.
1ï¸âƒ£ Hop 1 time.
3ï¸âƒ£ Hop 3 times.
ğŸ’¡Can you hop, then jump, then clap? 
ğŸ† Can you clap twice, jump once, and hop three times?
;
ğŸ’¡Remembering Instructions
Take turns playing a game where you give 2-3 instructions that the other person has to remember to follow. Make sure physical movement is included!
For example:
Hop twice, turn around.
Jump to the kitchen, pick up a spoon, then run back. âœ…

ltp_activity_data.name: Thinking Games
ltp_activity_data.text:
â— Mama/Daddy says! Play this game of giving instructions:
Mama/daddy says touch your head. Mama/daddy says open your mouth. Mama/daddy says turn around. Mama/daddy says touch your knees. Mama/daddy says jump twice. Mama/daddy says jump, then clap and sit.
;
ğŸ‘‚ Go and stop: Play the game with Your Child
Say: When I say â€œstopâ€, we freeze. When I say â€œgoâ€, we can walk again.
Once Your Child is familiar with the game, Your Child will lead.
;
ğŸ”µ ğŸ”´Blue-Red - now play this game!
If I say touch something blue, you need to touch something red. If I say touch something red, you need to touch something blue.

ltp_activity_data.name: Games with Pictures!
ltp_activity_data.text:
ğŸ‘‚ Making up a story from an image
For example, say: We are going to make up a story about this picture. I can start. This little girl is feeling very excited today. Why do you think she is feeling excited?
ğŸ˜ƒ She is holding her bag and has a big smile. Where do you think she is going?
;
ğŸ‘€ Can you point to it?
Using a book or a magazine, or anything with pictures, say:
I am going to describe something on the page and you need to guess what it is and point to it. For example, â€œI see something that is [green and moves slowly].
Can you guess what it is?â€ ğŸ’š

ltp_activity_data.name: Shapes Everywhere!
ltp_activity_data.text:
ğŸ“º Squares, squares everywhere

ğŸ‘€ Draw squares in the sand or dirt. Make some bigger and some smaller.
Tell Your Child, â€œthis is a square.â€ 
Ask your girl or boy to try to draw a square. Hold your boyâ€™s or girlâ€™s hand to help if this is hard. 
Look for things around the home or outdoors that are the same shape.

Now do the same with circles! ğŸ”´

ltp_activity_data.name: Story Telling
ltp_activity_data.text:
ğŸ’¡ Letâ€™s make a story!

Say: We are going to make up a story. I will start then you will help me continue it. 
â° â€Once upon a time there wasâ€¦â€
â€œWhat happened next?â€ğŸ‘€
â€œWhat happened after that?â€
;

ğŸ‘‚ Tell me the story!
Say to Your Child: â€œI have a book here that we have read before. Can you remember the story and tell it to me just by looking at the pictures?â€ 
ğŸ‘€ Show your girl or boy pictures in the book. Ask your boy or girl what is happening in the pictures and what happens next.

ltp_activity_data.name: I'm a Writer!
ltp_activity_data.text:
ğŸ“ Have fun being creative with writing!

You and Your Child can have fun writing with a pencil and paper, or with a stick and the sand!
If your girl or boy doesnâ€™t know how to write letters, encourage them to draw shapes, and try to copy the shapes of letters. ğŸ”µâ–¶ï¸

When they are more confident, encourage them to write letters and even words. ğŸ˜ƒStart showing them how to write their name and other important words for them, like mom, ball or milk.

Show them the simple things that you write - like shopping lists! Show them the words and each of the letters. Let them try to copy the words! ğŸ“–

ltp_activity_data.name: A Friendly Chat
ltp_activity_data.text:
Talk to your girl or boy about something that they are interested in! ğŸ˜ƒ

ğŸ’š Spending quality time with your boy or girl and talking to them every day is a good way to develop a strong relationship. 

âš½ An easy way to start talking to your girl or boy is to ask them about something they are interested in, for example you could talk about topics such as: sports, books, movies, friends, music, celebrities, or school.

ğŸ‘‚ You may not find everything your boy or girl shares to be interesting, but itâ€™s important to show enthusiasm and an eagerness to learn.

ltp_activity_data.name: Get Active
ltp_activity_data.text:
Exercise is a great way to spend time together and it is so good for your health. ğŸŒ± Find a sport or exercise that both you and your girl or boy want to do and try it out together! 

â° Even walking for 10 minutes a day is good for you. 

âš½ Together you can walk, run, play soccer, swim, dance, or do any other sport..

ğŸ† Together, think of ways to make it even more fun. Can you jog to a certain point? Take turns being the coach? Can there be a small, free reward, like getting to decide the next activity?

ğŸŒˆ Exercise becomes easier and more enjoyable the more you do it. 

ğŸ”„ If you or your girl or boy do not like the first exercise you pick, try a new exercise.

ltp_activity_data.name: Pass the Ball
ltp_activity_data.text:
Games are a great, fun way to spend time with your family! 

3ï¸âƒ£ This game is best with at least 3 people.

âš½ Find a ball to play. If you cannot find a ball, choose an item you can safely throw around. For example, a bottle cap or a plastic cup.

â¡ï¸ Start in a circle and pass the ball around. 

ğŸ‘‹ Start throwing the ball in new directions (up, down, straight, curved, rolling on the ground) and with different forces (hard, soft, medium). You can bounce the ball, throw it in the air, and catch it a few times before passing it. 

âœ¨ When everyone gets good at catching the ball, you can start moving around the room, still passing the ball. 

â­ Can you throw the ball under the leg? Behind the back? Over your head? Block a pass? Have fun with it!

ltp_activity_data.name: Active Songs
ltp_activity_data.text:
ğŸ˜ƒ Young boys and girls love physical games! But they need reminders about how to play ğŸ’¡
ğŸµ Songs with movements are fun and active and give instructions on how to move!
;
Sing songs to Your Child or a group of girls and boys in which they have to:
âœ… Start and stop âŒ
â¬‡ï¸ Slow down and speed up â¬†ï¸

ltp_activity_data.name: Follow the Leader!
ltp_activity_data.text:
â­ Choose someone to be the leader (tip: start with an adult like yourself)
ğŸ˜ƒ Other players line up behind the leader. The leader moves around in any way they like!
ğŸ They can run, jump, crawl, walk on tiptoe, and any other way they want!
ğŸ‘€ The other players must copy what the leader does, and the leader can change movements at any time.

ğŸ”„ Players take turns being the leader!

ltp_activity_data.name: Be the Narrator
ltp_activity_data.text:
ğŸ‘€ Say what your girl or boy is doing while they are playing

ğŸ‘‚ This will help them learn the words to describe their actions.

ğŸ˜ƒ You can do it in a simple way, or in a silly way like a sports commentator, a news presenter, or a game show host

ğŸ’¡ Ask questions like â€œwhat will you do next?â€ or â€œI see you want to put the ball in the jar. Is there another way to do that?â€

ltp_activity_data.name: Be an Artist!
ltp_activity_data.text:
ğŸ“ Give Your Child some paper and a pen or pencil, or some different pens or pencils.
ğŸ˜ƒ Let your girl or boy draw whatever they want to!
ğŸ‘€ Ask questions about what they are drawing, the size of the thing they are drawing, and the colours they are using.

ğŸ† If possible, put your boy or girlâ€™s picture up on the wall when they are finished. Give praise to your girl or boy!

ltp_activity_data.name: Be an Expert in Emotions!
ltp_activity_data.text:
ğŸ“ Create an album of the six emotions with Your Child: happy, sad, angry, disgusted, surprised, afraid.

Draw, cut-out pictures from magazines, or take photos of family members showing different emotions. 

Label each emotion and add words about how each family member feels those emotions. 

Put the album in a spot everyone agrees on, and use it throughout the day to show how the family is feeling. For example, after school, everyone can pin the emotion theyâ€™re experiencing. 

Feel free to add new feelings as they come up. If someone doesnâ€™t know what they are feeling, help them identify it by exploring how it feels in their body. Try together to find a new word for that emotion.

This can help everyone in the family become experts in understanding themselves and be aware of what their bodies need.
